results.title: The Rise of Hitler
results.creator_credit: Films Incorporated, Jack Kaufman and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode no. 1 of Series “The Rise and fall of the Third Reich”
The first of a three part series based on William Shirer’s book. Traces the life of Adolf Hitler from his childhood to his rise as chancellor.

results.title: Gotterdammerung: fall of the Third Reich
results.creator_credit: Jack Kaufman, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Rise and fall of the Third Reich”.
Third and final part of a series based on the book by William L. Shirer ‘The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich’. This episode deals with the period 1941-1945, showing the first gradual and then accelerated reverses of the German army.

results.title: Nazi Germany: years of triumph
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Rise and fall of the Third Reich”.
Second episode of a three part series. Covers the period prior to the Reichstag fire in 1932 to the Dunkirk evacuation. Based on the book by William L. Shirer. Narrated by Richard Basehart. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Pollution from chimney stacks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
CSIRO’s research on pollution from chimney stacks: fly ash (a fine grey powder produced whenever coal is bunrt). Coal power stations conventionally use electrostatic precipitators to remove fly ash before its released into the atmosphere. The CSIRO has developed a more efficient containment of fly ash effectively reducing pollution and producing more ingredients for cement manufacture.

results.title: In a nutshell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Australian gum trees are of considerable economic importance in various parts of the world. This demand is met by providing gum seeds to the countries that want our nuts.

results.title: Nature's complete food
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
In the rainforests of Central America grows a most unusual tree. It produces nature’s most complete food…the avocado. The avocado tree grows quite happily in temperate Australia, but it doesn’t always produce good crops. CSIRO scientist Dr Margaret Sedgley has been finding out why. The avocado’s erratic behaviour seems due to adverse temperatures. CSIRO’s research has focused on the two most important varieties - smooth-skinned Fuerte, and rough-skinned hass. North-western Victoria is an important new area for avocado growing. Here the researchers are looking at another problem. Irrigation water from the Murray may cause salt damage to trees at certain times of the year. Whether it’s possible to solve some of these problems of growing avocados in Australian conditions, only time and further research will tell.

results.title: Yellow dog dingo
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Graziers have claimed for years that the dingo is responsible for heavy stock losses, specially among sheep. The Australian Meat Research Committee responded by earmarking funds for a scientific study of the dog. A team from the CSIRO’s Division of Wildlife Research in Canberra was mobilised in 1966 to carry out the study. Across Central Australia and the East Coast, the dogs were observed, tracked and examined in their own domain for thousands of hours. The difficulty it seems is that there is no one answer for dingo management in the scientific sense for any place in Australia and any one answer therefore for all of Australia. Management will have to be much more flexible, changing from place to place and from time to time.
